Interviews and observations clarify the role of TOP factors in CMMS use in industrial maintenance.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nFindings<\/jats:title>\nIn total, 17 detailed TOP factors are identified and criteria for analyzing CMMS contexts with them are defined. Analyzing the cases with these factors reveals that technicians who collect good quality data have received good training and instructions for the CMMS, are competent, and understand how manually collected data benefits them in their own work. However, even these sites struggle with the usability of the CMMS.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nResearch limitations\/implications<\/jats:title>\nThe 17 TOP factors and the criteria for CMMS evaluation extend understanding on context and usability in manual data collection. Case study method does not imply the relative importance of the TOP factors, which calls for future research using quantitative methods.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nPractical implications<\/jats:title>\nManagement can use the criteria to analyze the context of manual data collection for improvements, e.g., in CMMS usability.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nOriginality\/value<\/jats:title>\nInsights from industrial environments and a new way of studying contextual factors of CMMS use are presented.
